Green’s Theorem in the Plane

This states that

\(\displaystyle \qquad \oint_C (P \mathrm{d}x + Q \mathrm{d}y) = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left( \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial y} \right) \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y\)

\(S\) is a \(2\)-\(D\) surface with perimeter \(C\); \(P(x,y)\) and \(Q(x,y)\) are scalar functions.

This should not be confused with Green’s identities.

Justification of Green's Theorem in the Plane

Green’s theorem in the plane can be derived from Stokes’ theorem.

\(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\)

Now let \(\underline{F}\) be the vector field \(P(x,y) \underline{i} + Q(x,y) \underline{j}\) i.e. there is no dependence on \(z\) and there are no components in the \(z-\) direction. Now


\({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = \left|\begin{array}{ccc} \underline{i} & \underline{j} & \underline{k} \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ P(x,y) & Q(x,y) & 0 \end{array} \right| = \left( \dfrac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \dfrac{\partial P}{\partial y} \right) \underline{k}\)
and \(\underline{dS} = \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y \underline{k}\) giving \(({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{dS} = \left( \dfrac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \dfrac{\partial P}{\partial y} \right) \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y\).

Thus Stokes’ theorem becomes

\(\displaystyle \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left( \dfrac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \dfrac{\partial P}{\partial y} \right) \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y = \displaystyle\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\)

and Green’s theorem in the plane follows.

Key Point

Green's Theorem in the Plane

\[\oint_C (P \mathrm{d}x + Q \mathrm{d}y) = \int\!\! \int_S \left( \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial y} \right)\ \mathrm{d}x\ \mathrm{d}y \]

This relates a line integral around a closed path \(C\) with a double integral over the region \(S\) enclosed by \(C\). It is effectively a two-dimensional form of Stokes' theorem.

Example

Evaluate the line integral \(\displaystyle\oint_C \left[(4x^2 + y - 3)\mathrm{d}x + (3x^2 + 4 y^2 - 2)\mathrm{d}y \right]\) around the rectangle \(0 \le x \le 3\), \(0 \le y \le 1\).

Solution

The integral could be obtained by evaluating four line integrals but it is easier to note that \(\left[(4x^2 + y - 3)\mathrm{d}x + (3x^2 + 4 y^2 - 2)\mathrm{d}y \right]\) is of the form \(P \mathrm{d}x + Q \mathrm{d}y\) with \(P = 4x^2 + y - 3\) and \(Q = 3x^2 + 4y^2 -2\). It is thus of a suitable form for Green's theorem in the plane. Note that \(\dfrac{\partial Q}{\partial x} = 6x\) and \(\dfrac{\partial P}{\partial y} = 1\). Green's theorem in the plane becomes \begin{eqnarray*} \displaystyle\oint_C \{(4x^2 + y - 3) \mathrm{d}x + (3x^2 + 4y^2 -2) \mathrm{d}y\} &=& \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^3 \left( 6x - 1 \right) \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y \\ &=& \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \left[ \phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\! 3x^2 - x \right]_{x=0}^3 \mathrm{d}y = \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 24 \ \mathrm{d}y = 24 \\ \end{eqnarray*}

Example

Verify Green’s theorem in the plane for the integral \(\displaystyle\oint_C \left[ 4 z \mathrm{d}y + (y^2 - 2)\mathrm{d}z \right]\) and the triangular contour starting at the origin \(O = (0,0,0)\) and going to \(A = (0,2,0)\) and \(B = (0,0,1)\) before returning to the origin.

Solution

The whole of the contour is in the plane \(x=0\) and Green's theorem in the plane becomes

\(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\oint_C (P \mathrm{d}y + Q \mathrm{d}z) = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left( \frac{\partial Q}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial z} \right) \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}z \)

(a) Firstly evaluate \( \displaystyle\oint_C \left\{ 4 z \mathrm{d}y + (y^2 - 2)\mathrm{d}z \right\}\).

On \(OA\), \(z=0\) and \(\mathrm{d}z = 0\). As the integrand is zero, the integral will also be zero.

On \(AB\), \(z = (1 - \frac{y}{2})\) and \(\mathrm{d}z = -\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{d}y\). The integral is

\( \displaystyle\int_{y=2}^0 \left( (4 - 2y) \mathrm{d}y - \frac{1}{2} (y^2 - 2) \mathrm{d}y \right) = \displaystyle\int_2^0 (5 - 2y - \frac{1}{2} y^2 ) \mathrm{d}y = \left[ 5 y - y^2 - \frac{1}{6}y^3 \right]_2^0 = -\frac{14}{3}\)

On \(BO\), \(y=0\) and \(\mathrm{d}y=0\). The integral is \( \displaystyle\int_1^0 (-2 ) \mathrm{d}z = \left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\!-2z \right]_1^0 = 2\).

Summing, \( \displaystyle\oint_C \left( 4 z \mathrm{d}y + (y^2 - 2)\mathrm{d}z \right) = -\frac{8}{3}\)

(b) Secondly evaluate \(\displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left( \frac{\partial Q}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial z} \right) \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}z \)

In this example, \(P = 4z\) and \(Q = y^2 - 2\). Thus \(\dfrac{\partial P}{\partial z} = 4\) and \(\dfrac{\partial Q}{\partial y} = 2 y\). Hence,

\(\begin{align} \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left( \frac{\partial Q}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial z} \right) \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}z &= \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^2 \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^{1-y/2} \left( 2y - 4 \right) \mathrm{d}z\mathrm{d}y \\ &= \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^2 \left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\! 2 y z - 4 z \right]_{z=0}^{1-y/2} \mathrm{d}y = \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^2 \left( -y^2 + 4 y - 4 \right) \mathrm{d}y\qquad\qquad \\ &= \left[ -\frac{1}{3}y^3 + 2 y^2 - 4 y \right]_0^2 = -\frac{8}{3} \end{align} \)

Hence:

\(\displaystyle \displaystyle\oint_C (P \mathrm{d}y + Q \mathrm{d}z) = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left( \frac{\partial Q}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial z} \right) \mathrm{d}y \mathrm{d}z = -\frac{8}{3}\) and Green's theorem in the plane is verified.

One very useful, special case of Green’s theorem in the plane is when \(Q=x\) and \(P=-y\). The theorem becomes

\(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\oint_C \{-y \mathrm{d}x + x \mathrm{d}y\} = \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S \left( 1 - (-1) \right) \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y\)

The right-hand side becomes \(\displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S 2\; \mathrm{d}x \mathrm{d}y\) i.e. \(2A\) where \(A\) is the area inside the contour \(C\). Hence

\(\qquad\displaystyle A = \frac{1}{2} \displaystyle\oint_C \{x \mathrm{d}y - y \mathrm{d}x\}\)

This result is known as the area theorem. It gives us the area bounded by a curve \(C\) in terms of a line integral around \(C\).

Example

Verify the area theorem for the segment of the circle \(x^2 + y^2 = 4\) lying above the line \(y = 1\).

Solution

Firstly, the area of the segment \(ADBC\) can be found by subtracting the area of the triangle \(OADB\) from the area of the sector \(OACB\). The triangle has area \(\frac{1}{2} \times 2\sqrt{3} \times 1 = \sqrt{3}\). The sector has area \(\frac{\pi}{3} \times 2^2 = \frac{4}{3}\pi\). Thus segment \(ADBC\) has area \(\frac{4}{3}\pi - \sqrt{3}\).

Now, evaluate the integral \( \displaystyle\oint_C \{x \mathrm{d}y - y \mathrm{d}x\}\) around the segment.

Along the line, \(y = 1\), \(\mathrm{d}y = 0\) so the integral \( \displaystyle\int_C \{x \mathrm{d}y - y \mathrm{d}x\}\) becomes \( \displaystyle\int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{3}} (x \times 0 - 1\times \mathrm{d}x) = \displaystyle\int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{3}}(- \mathrm{d}x) = - 2\sqrt{3}\).

Along the arc of the circle, \(y = \sqrt{4-x^2} = (4-x^2)^{1/2}\) so \(\mathrm{d}y = -x (4-x^2)^{-1/2} \mathrm{d}x\).

The integral \( \displaystyle\int_C \{x \mathrm{d}y - y \mathrm{d}x\}\) becomes

\[\begin{align} \displaystyle\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{-\sqrt{3}} \{-x^2(4-x^2)^{-1/2} - (4-x^2)^{1/2}\}\mathrm{d}x &= \displaystyle\int_{-\sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{3}} \dfrac{4}{\sqrt{4-x^2}}\mathrm{d}x \\ &= \displaystyle\int_{-\pi/3}^{\pi/3} 4 \frac{1}{2\cos\theta}2\cos\theta\ d\theta \mbox { (letting \(x=2 \sin \theta\))}\\ &= \displaystyle\int_{-\pi/3}^{\pi/3} 4 d\theta = \frac{8}{3}\pi \\ \end{align} \]

So, \(\dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle\oint_C \{x \mathrm{d}y - y \mathrm{d}x\} = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \frac{8}{3}\pi - 2\sqrt{3}\right] = \frac{4}{3}\pi - \sqrt{3}. \)

Hence both sides of the area theorem equal \( \ \dfrac{4}{3}\pi - \sqrt{3}\) thus verifying the theorem.
